threads.com: My answer was 11.62g O2. Got it by multiplying 0.12106928391 with 3 and 32. Can someone post their solutions so I can see which step I messed up with and got the answer wrong.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1282892
15 grams P4 is completely reacted. How many mols is this?
= 15 g P4 * (1/30.974 mol /g P4)
= 0.4197 mol P4

How many mols of oxygen will react with 0.4197 mol P4?
We must first balance the equation (you should know how to do this)
>P4+3 O2=2 P4O2
So, 3 mol of O2 per mol of P4.
0.4197 mol P4 * (3 mol O2 / 1 g P4) = 1.6788 mol O2

How many grams of oxygen is this?
1.6788 mol O2 * 16.0 g O2 / mol O2 = 26.8608 g O2

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>1282531
>But how is the "quality" and the writing of the textbooks and other sources of learning?
It is very limited. Academic content on general subjects is literally like content in English except of shittier quality. They just translate English stuff or write books which contain the same thing except they have their names on it. Back in college I really hated when we had to use sources released in my country's language even though I could read and write English. I remember asking instructors if I can submit papers in English and they were like NOOOOOOOO YOU CAN'T DO TAHT.
The only exception is when your research involves stuff specific to that given language. Papers on say Serbian literature or law will most likely be in Serbian.

It's also stunning how much better American textbooks are than European ones. American textbooks teach you shit in an easy to understand and practical way as if they wanted you to learn, while European textbooks present shit in a contrived theoretical way with little regards to practicality, as if they were made to gatekeep students while showing off the author's superiority.

tl;dr use English

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: How to calculate cache miss rate?
threads.com:
Currently I need to calculate a cache miss rate to check a result.

I just have these informations:
Total size = 4096
Line size = 16
Line per set = 1
Num sets = 256
data size = 64
Miss rate = 0.5

I just would to understand how to find this result (0.5) with these information?

Thank you for your time.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1282618
>how to find this result (0.5) with these information?
You can't. Just for starters, you don't know how big the thing it's caching is, so you can't even calculate a miss rate against a hypothetical access pattern.
As a pathological example, if I did repeated linear reads of main memory*, the miss rate would be 100%, because (assuming main memory is bigger than the cache) every read is guaranteed to not be in the cache yet, and guaranteed to have been evicted by the time I get to it again.

* which is a pathological example, but not a ridiculous or contrived one: a naive approach to hybrid suspending an OS might go:
- read main memory and write out a compressed version over the memory you've already read
- read the compressed version again and write it to disk
- suspend
- if we find ourselves unsuspending, move the compressed memory dump to the end of memory, then go back to the start and uncompress it

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
There also was a function to calculate the dot product of two numbers.

I have this refurbished iPhone 7 running iOS 15.7.1.
The problem was also present in 15.6.1.
I bought it recently and factory reset it with iTunes.
No jailbreak or anything.

Every so often, usually when I unlock the phone, a weird drawer pulls down from the top.
Sometimes, if I stroke the middle of the bottom bar downward 1-20 times, I can get it to appear.
Other times, it just doesn't appear at all, no matter how much I try.

It nudges the rest of the screen downward, which I can still interact with while it's down.
It disappears on its own by pulling itself up after a few seconds.
If I pull down on the arrow, the notifications drawer pulls down, and the mystery drawer pulls up.
But if I pull it up first, then I can drag it up and down.
When I let go, it disappears.

There's nothing in the drawer and I can't figure out what it's for.
It's not the "Siri Suggestions" screen that appears when pulling down on the main screen.
It's also not the Control Center screen that appears when stroking upward from the bottom.

What even is this drawer?
Is it just a weird iOS bug?
Anyone else experiencing this?

my car's left headlight isn't working
I made sure the bulb and the fuse were still working and im not sure what to check next
its a 2000 camry btw

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1282431
>not sure what to check next
There's really not that much to them:
- if they're on a relay, check the relay (pull it out, short its switched terminals together, light lights = bad relay)
- if they're not on a relay, check the wiring all the way back to the switch (and then the fuse board!) until you find 12V
- if the other light is working it's probably not the switch, so look at wiring.
